key_insight: MemFlow replaces fixed, one-size-fits-all memory compression with a flowing, content-adaptive memory that selectively retains and updates historical cues per upcoming video chunk, enabling consistent long-range video narratives with lower cost.
problem_solved: Addresses the difficulty of maintaining content consistency across long streaming video contexts where predetermined memory-compression strategies fail to preserve the varied historical cues different future chunks require.
method: Adaptive memory flow: dynamically select and route relevant historical frames/features conditioned on the next chunks to generate, rather than applying a fixed compression policy.
Content-aware retention/compression: compress or expand stored representations based on their predicted relevance to upcoming generation, keeping high-fidelity cues when needed.
Streaming-efficient updates: incrementally update the memory in a lightweight manner to support long-context generation with reduced compute and memory footprints.
impact: Makes long-form and streaming video generation more consistent and scalable, benefiting practitioners building real-time synthesis, long narrative generation, and memory-augmented generative models. It reduces the trade-off between temporal fidelity and efficiency.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram showing incoming frames → adaptive memory module (select/retain/compress) → generator, highlighting the 'flow' of memory.
Side-by-side frame sequence comparison (fixed-memory vs MemFlow) to illustrate improved temporal consistency.
Timeline heatmap showing memory relevance scores over long context (which frames are retained/discarded) to visualize adaptive retention.
Bar chart comparing memory usage / latency / coherence metrics between MemFlow and baseline fixed-strategy methods.
paper_title: MemFlow: Flowing Adaptive Memory for Consistent and Efficient Long Video Narratives
paper_authors: Sihui Ji, Xi Chen, Shuai Yang, Xin Tao, Pengfei Wan
